Award.AwardTitle: Cells as an Intelligent Material: An integrated multiscale modeling approach based on coupled responses to chemical, electrical, and mechanical stimuli

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit
The research objective of this project is to provide a thorough methodology for the creation of advanced networks of cellular mimics. The natural world often exhibits elegant solutions to complex engineering problems, many of which are derived from phenomena exhibited at the cellular level. It is possible to recreate some of these desired behaviors and provide insight into how networks of individual cells can display collective behaviors by creating networks of cellular mimics in the laboratory. This multi-disciplinary project focuses on coupling experimental, computational, and theoretical approaches to aid in the development of a multiscale model for predicting the behavior of these artificial cellular networks, focusing on their unique transduction capabilities and responses to various stimuli. The approach will involve the creation of individual biomolecular unit cells, constructing a multiscale model for predicting the behavior of networks of these unit cells, validating the model through the experimental results, and applying the validated model towards more advanced systems demonstrating the potential in using cellular mimics as intelligent materials.

Broader Impacts
The benefits of this multi-disciplinary research include a more in-depth understanding of cellular networks through theoretical, computational, and experimental efforts. The findings will provide insight into how cells work in parallel to achieve collective goals, and illustrate the potential for biologically-inspired approaches in engineering research by demonstrating how cellular mechanics may be harnessed for tackling complex problems. These dual goals will aid in increasing collaboration between the biological and engineering worlds and may lead to further scientific discoveries through fresh perspectives. Cells demonstrate the same characteristics as many traditional intelligent materials, and properly tailored networks of cellular mimics may offer possibilities for the design of new devices such as microactuators and sensors. In addition, a new generation of biologically-minded engineers will be encouraged through high school and undergraduate seminars that highlight applications of biomimetic design.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Cellular materials are a new class of biological material whose structure is inspired by cellular mechanics, built piece-by-piece from water droplets in oil with dissolved lipids through the droplet interface bilayer technique. The primary focus of this project was examining the mechanics of these membrane-based materials so that researchers may better adapt them for day-to-day engineering applications such as sensing and energy conversion.  This allowed for improved designs for the materials, as well as allowing for insights into the mechanics of naturally occurring membranes.

This was accomplished by examining the material from the ground up, beginning with the role each individual molecular component plays in the transport of electric current and fluid throughout the material.  This allowed for an expanded understanding of how the material may be used, and led to new discoveries in the coupled mechanical-electrical response of the membrane.  These improvements led to new experimental techniques for characterizing the composition of the membrane and new sensors which convert mechanical vibrations into energy.  Next-generation iterations were also investigated, including the interaction of the material with living organisms such as bacteria.

The grant also provided support for the development of molecular models for studying properties of the membranes that were not accessible using the droplet interface bilayer platform due to the inherent surface tensions.  The orientation of the individual lipid molecules within the membrane were simulated and tracked using coarse-grained techniques, and the magnitude of these orientations were successfully mapped back to the bending stiffness of the given membrane.  Lipid mixtures containing varying head groups and tails were synthesized, and trends relating the lipid structure to the overall membrane properties were obtained.  This provided a road-map for selecting proper lipid composition when designing tough and durable membrane structures.

These computational results were validated in the laboratory using electroformed liposomes.  These liposomes were studied using a fundamentally similar technique as described above, examining the undulations of the liposome surface rather than the individual lipid orientation.  This provided a similar result for the bending stiffness, unifying the problem from two very different perspectives.

The grant provided partial training for one postdoctoral associate, partial training for 2 Ph.D. candidates, and full training for 2 M.S. students in disciplines including mechanical engineering, biological engineering, and electronics engineering.  Students supported on the grant presented their work at multiple nationally-recognized conference.  The grant also supported the development of multiple research projects for undergraduates and high school students, showing them the inherent potential of interdisciplinary collaborations.
